dlgPart.npc_text:
You enter the tent. Several armed men are sitting on the carpets thrown on the ground, laughing and talking. The decorations are simple. It doesn’t seem that the khan has much use for gold or works of art. There is a throne that seems out of place in this tent – probably taken from some lord and kept as an inside joke.
The men slowly get up. One of them looks at you and says formally, “I grant you guest rights in my camp and my ger. Now speak!”
“I asked for steel yet Gaelius sends me more greetings. Is this the way of the southern khans?”

dlgAnsw.text: Calm him down. “It’s waiting for you in Maadoran.”
Provoke him. “Who are you to question Lord Gaelius? Now that you’ve agreed to serve him, you will do wise to remember your place.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I told the man who came before you – my people are divided. Some would rather stay here than give up our ways and live in tents made of stone. To bridge the gap I need to give them something, to show them why this alliance is good for the people. You understand?”

“Talk,” scoffs the khan. “That’s all you city dwellers do. You should let good steel do the talking for you... But you’re here and steel isn’t. Talk to Belgutai. He is one of my commanders. A lord of a thousand warriors. A year ago he would have drunk my piss to prove his loyalty, but today he thinks he can oppose me.”
“A warrior could challenge Belgutai, but you don't look like one.”
“You have the look of a warrior. If you were to challenge Belgutai...”

dlgAnsw.text: “I'll go talk to him then.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “I can order the men who are still loyal to me to attack those who are loyal to our ways. Is this what your khan wants me to do? Is this why he sent me no weapons?”

“Why? Because he doesn’t know better. Belgutai is young. The warrior’s way is the only way he knows. He believes only in his sword and sees no further than its tip. He thinks that the sky-father is testing us, that if we stay on the plains and survive, we will grow stronger and will be able to defeat our enemies. He isn’t alone in his thoughts.
“That’s why we haven’t moved yet. I don’t want to risk an open confrontation. Many people will side with him, if he chooses to oppose me. They call him Bolad reborn.”

dlgAnsw.text: “I'll go talk to him then.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “Bolad was a great warrior who lived a long time ago. He had the strength of a bear and the speed of a tiger and could cut down ten men in the blink of an eye. There are many stories of his deeds and battles. Such was his glory that the sky-father himself decided to honor him with a gift.”

The khan nods. “A powerful shaman appeared before the khan one day and told him that he had come for Bolad. Our warriors attacked him, but neither swords nor arrows could touch him.
“The shaman said that the sky-father had a gift for Bolad and that he had to travel with him to receive it. A gift from the sky-father is a great honor. Bolad could not refuse, so they left together, never to be seen again.
“Ever since it was every warrior’s dream to be as good as Bolad and be honored by the sky-father.”
“Nobody was as good as Bolad.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do your stories say about the Great War?”
“Do your stories say anything about the Qantari?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “His name was Adad. He had many charms about him to ward off spirits and a helmet made of crystal. The legends say that this is how he was able to speak to the sky-father.”

dlgAnsw.text: [intelligence success]"Hadad? Abu Hassan Ibn Hadad? The Magus?"
[lore success]"Hadad? Abu Hassan Ibn Hadad? The Magus?"
“What do your stories say about the Great War?”
“Do your stories say anything about the Qantari?”

dlgPart.npc_text: "Adad, Hadad... What does it matter? The story isn't about the shaman. It's about Bolad, a mighty hero who was honored by the sky-father. The shaman was just a messenger."

dlgAnsw.text: “What do your stories say about the Great War?”
“Do your stories say anything about the Qantari?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “The legends say it was before the Great War that burned the land.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do your stories say about the Great War?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “They say the Great War was unlike any that came before. They say it was a testament to the spirit and ferocity of men who lived in those days. Small men fight small wars. Great men fight great wars.”

dlgAnsw.text: “You make it sound like it’s a good thing.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “War is a measure of men. A wolf is born to kill. A rabbit is born to be eaten. Each man is given a choice, to be a wolf or a rabbit. If you choose to be a rabbit, don’t complain when the wolves come.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Do your stories say anything about the Qantari?”
“Why did you accept Gaelius’ offer then?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “The brown men from across the Great Sea? My people took their measure of them many times – they fought fiercely and fell on us like a tempest, yet fell like grass before our swords.”

dlgAnsw.text: “The stories I’ve heard say that they were mighty warriors.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Then they speak of their shamans. They were numerous and used many tricks to drive our people back.”

dlgAnsw.text: “How strong were your people in those days?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “The Great Khan commanded seventeen tumens; each tumen had ten thousand warriors. Nothing could stand in his way, not even a Tngri.”

“They are spirits who dwell in the spirit realm. They number ninety nine and often take interest in the affairs of men. The greatest among them are the Nine Great Tngri – the Lord-Spirits, in your language. It is said that seven of them were called upon by the shamans during the Great War. Drunk on blood that was flowing like water, the Tngri fought the armies of men and each other.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Did the Ordu ever fight the Tngri?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “We did. Our paths crossed one day. The people’s path continued. The Tngri’s didn’t.”
“The victory was not without cost. Four tumens perished that day, but in the end the Tngri and the brown men who came with him were slain.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What do your stories say about the Great War?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “You have to know your enemy.”

dlgAnsw.text: “What about the alliance with Lord Gaelius?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “We need each other. It doesn’t make us friends. It makes us old enemies who have discovered common interests.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Do your stories say anything about the Qantari?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “I had no choice. The people won’t survive another winter on the plains. The plains are dying and if we stay here, we will die with them. Gaelius’ offer means life, but it also means death, for the future generations won’t know the ways of the endless plains and open sky. They will become soft like the city dwellers and this will be our undoing.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Do your stories say anything about the Qantari?”

dlgPart.npc_text: END
“And what is my place?” asks the khan calmly, stopping his bondsmen with a gesture.

dlgAnsw.text: “Forgive me, khan. I’ve chosen my words poorly. You will receive everything you need in Maadoran.”

“That of any vassal, of course. You and your men will be given food and lodging in exchange for faithful service and obedience. You will lead your men as their khan, for as long as my lord is pleased with your service. If not, another will take your place.”

dlgPart.npc_text:
“I’m puzzled,” says the khan, managing to control himself. “The other emissaries carried a very different message. They spoke honeyed words of friendship and new beginnings. You speak as one would to a dog.
“I would please me to watch you killed, but business must always come before pleasure. Explain khan Gaelius’ change of heart to me and I’ll grant you a clean death.”

dlgAnsw.text: [persuasion]“Did you really think that you’d come to Maadoran as Gaelius’ equal? On these plains you are a khan, but in Maadoran you’ll be Gaelius’ dog kept on a short leash, lest it bites its owner. I thought you knew that.”

[streetwise]“You have only yourself to blame, Thorgul. The honeyed words you liked so much didn’t get you to Maadoran, did they? My lord grows impatient. He’s even threatened to have you whipped when you’d finally show up.”

dlgPart.npc_text: [failure]“No,” says the khan shaking his head. “Something is amiss here. Take <him/her> away!”

[success]“I thank you, messenger, for finally delivering me straight words. I’ll let you live, for I want you to carry a message to Gaelius. He’ll get his wish and we’ll come to Maadoran. Not today and not tomorrow, but when we’re ready; and when we do, Maadoran will fall.”
The khan’s bondsmen take you to a small tent, serving as prison. “Your weapons!” demands one of them.
It looks like the noise of the fight was drowned in the noise of the camp. You put on the Ordu armor and slip away quietly.

dlgAnsw.text: You recall seeing a well in the middle of the camp. Perhaps, a healthy dose of poison would calm the Ordu down a bit.

You approach the well. It looks like it’s the only source of water for miles around and you just happen to have a vial of poison. The only problem is that you’re surrounded by people and a slight misstep will be the end of you. A very painful end, most likely.

[failure]You pull up a bucket of water and drink, holding the bucket with both hands. When you put the bucket down, you try to empty the vial with poison into it as inconspicuously as humanly possible, but a woman nearby sees it and starts yelling something in her language, pointing at you with her finger.
Within moments, you’re stretched on the ground and large quantities of water are poured down your throat. When the Ordu are satisfied, they let you go and watch you with interest, exchanging quick comments.
You feel a knot on your stomach and take a few uneasy steps. Suddenly, your legs give in and you drop on your knees. The knot in your stomach is growing bigger and bigger, making it difficult to breathe. You feel too dizzy even to sit and lie on your side, barely aware of where you are or what’s happening to you. It’s getting harder and harder to breathe and you feel very tired. You close your eyes and never open them again.

dlgAnsw.text: Not exactly what you had in mind...

dlgPart.npc_text:
[success]You pull up a bucket of water and drink, holding the bucket with both hands. When you put the bucket down, you manage to empty the vial with poison into it without anyone noticing and drop the bucket back down the well.
You doubt that the poison would kill them, but it might weaken them and make the upcoming battle easier.
DEAD
“Speak,” says Thorgul tiredly.

dlgAnsw.text: “Belgutai agreed to go with you to Maadoran.”
“Belgutai doesn’t want to listen to reason.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Nothing. If you wish to know more, talk to the keeper of stories. It is her duty to the tribe to remember battles long gone and inspire warriors with her tales.”

“I knew he would come around,” nods Thorgul. “Where is he? It’s time to bury our differences.” He gestures and his bondsmen let Belgutai in. He approaches the khan and bows to him, saying something quietly. Something flashes in Thorgul’s eyes, but he accepts what was said and turns to you.

dlgAnsw.text: [guard]“I will go to the pass and prepare it for your arrival.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “A city dweller killed my best warrior. I don’t know whether to be glad that a man who opposed me is dead or mourn his death.”

dlgAnsw.text: [guard]“I will go to the pass and prepare it for your arrival.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “A woman killed my best warrior. It’s a sad day for the people.”

dlgAnsw.text: [guard]“I will go to the pass and prepare it for your arrival.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “I owe you a debt of gratitude,” says Thorgul. “I could not wish for a better outcome. Belgutai is dead, slain by my own hand after challenging me in front of witnesses. Nobody needs to know that he was unarmed. He challenged me and we fought. Every man will follow me to death and beyond now.”

dlgAnsw.text: [guard]“I will go to the pass and prepare it for your arrival.” Leave.

dlgPart.npc_text: “The pass blocks our way. My warriors will attack it, while you rest in my tent as befits the emissary of a great khan. Once the pass is taken, we’ll continue our journey to your city.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Good plan. Send for some wine and comely wenches!”
“It would take too long. Bass has probably fortified the pass by now and sent for reinforcements. If they arrive, we will be stuck at the pass.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “We drink airag – fermented milk of our mares.”

dlgAnsw.text: “I’ve drunk plenty of beer that tasted like horse piss. Might as well try horse milk now. How bad can it be, eh?” Party while other men die.

dlgPart.npc_text: “Can you return to the fort without raising suspicions?”

dlgAnsw.text: “No, I will be attacked on sight.”

dlgPart.npc_text: “Then nothing else can be done.”

dlgAnsw.text: Wait until the pass is taken.

dlgPart.npc_text:
“There are several crates of black powder at the fort. If not destroyed, it will be used against my people and many will die. I suspect the crates will be well guarded, for in the time of war this powder is more precious than gold or steel.
“If your warrior spirit is strong, go and be the first to spill the enemy’s blood. If not, stay here. Your khan won’t thank us if his trusted messenger is the first to die.”

dlgAnsw.text: “On second thought, I *am* too valuable to risk my life needlessly, aren’t I?” Wait until the pass is taken.
“How do you know about these crates?”

dlgPart.npc_text: “The soldiers don’t trade with us, but people who pass through the fort do. They sell us goods and information.”

dlgAnsw.text: “On second thought, I *am* too valuable to risk my life needlessly, aren’t I?” Wait until the pass is taken.

dlgPart.npc_text: “Belgutai puts all his hope in his scouts. We have no choice but to wait for them to return.”

dlgAnsw.text: Wait for the scouts to return.

dlgPart.npc_text:
You spend the next few days waiting for the scouts and getting to know the Ordu better. At the end of the third day the scouts return, empty-handed.
“Belgutai needed to know,” says Thorgul. “Now that he does, he will question my decision no longer.”
“My warriors are ready to attack the pass now. The honor to lead them is yours.”

dlgAnsw.text: “Me *and* your warriors? Sounds like overkill, but if you think it’s for the best...” Lead the attack.
